title: Adult Self-Report Scale (ASRS v1.1) for ADHD
description: Screens and diagnoses adult ADHD based on DSM-IV-TR criteria using an 18-question self-report questionnaire

parameters.name: q1_wrapping_details
parameters.description: How often do you have trouble wrapping up the final details of a project, once the challenging parts have been done?

parameters.name: q2_organization
parameters.description: How often do you have difficulty getting things in order when you have to do a task that requires organization?

parameters.name: q3_appointments
parameters.description: How often do you have problems remembering appointments or obligations?

parameters.name: q4_avoidance
parameters.description: When you have a task that requires a lot of thought, how often do you avoid or delay getting started?

parameters.name: q5_fidgeting
parameters.description: How often do you fidget or squirm with your hands or feet when you have to sit down for a long time?

parameters.name: q6_hyperactivity
parameters.description: How often do you feel overly active and compelled to do things, like you were driven by a motor?

parameters.name: q7_careless_mistakes
parameters.description: How often do you make careless mistakes when you have to work on a boring or difficult project?

parameters.name: q8_attention_difficulty
parameters.description: How often do you have difficulty keeping your attention when you are doing boring or repetitive work?

parameters.name: q9_concentration
parameters.description: How often do you have difficulty concentrating on what people say to you, even when they are speaking to you directly?

parameters.name: q10_misplacing
parameters.description: How often do you misplace or have difficulty finding things at home or at work?

parameters.name: q11_distractibility
parameters.description: How often are you distracted by activity or noise around you?

parameters.name: q12_leaving_seat
parameters.description: How often do you leave your seat in meetings or other situations in which you are expected to remain seated?

parameters.name: q13_restlessness
parameters.description: How often do you feel restless or fidgety?

parameters.name: q14_difficulty_relaxing
parameters.description: How often do you have difficulty unwinding and relaxing when you have time to yourself?

parameters.name: q15_talking_too_much
parameters.description: How often do you find yourself talking too much when you are in social situations?

parameters.name: q16_finishing_sentences
parameters.description: When you're in a conversation, how often do you find yourself finishing the sentences of the people you are talking to, before they can finish them themselves?

parameters.name: q17_waiting_turn
parameters.description: How often do you have difficulty waiting your turn in situations when turn taking is required?

parameters.name: q18_interrupting
parameters.description: How often do you interrupt others when they are busy?

result.name: screening_result
result.description: ADHD screening result with Part A score

ranges.interpretation: Screening negative for ADHD. Score <4 on Part A indicates symptoms are less likely to be consistent with adult ADHD.
Screening positive for ADHD. Score ≥4 on Part A indicates symptoms highly consistent with adult ADHD. Further clinical evaluation is warranted.

references: Kessler RC, Adler L, Ames M, Demler O, Faraone S, Hiripi E, et al. The World Health Organization Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS): a short screening scale for use in the general population. Psychol Med. 2005 Feb;35(2):245-56. doi: 10.1017/s0033291704002892.
Schweitzer JB, Cummins TK, Kant CA. Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder. Med Clin North Am. 2001 May;85(3):757-77. doi: 10.1016/s0025-7125(05)70348-2.

Adler LA, Spencer T, Faraone SV, Kessler RC, Howes MJ, Biederman J, et al. Validity of pilot Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS) to Rate Adult ADHD symptoms. Ann Clin Psychiatry. 2006 Jul-Sep;18(3):145-8. doi: 10.1080/10401230600801077.
formula: Part A (questions 1-6) is scored using specific thresholds. Part B (questions 7-18) provides additional clinical information. A score of ≥4 on Part A indicates positive screening.
notes: Developed in collaboration with WHO and Harvard Medical School researchers
Based on DSM-IV-TR criteria for ADHD
Part A (questions 1-6) serves as the primary screener with weighted scoring
Part B (questions 7-18) provides additional clinical information
Intended for adults aged 18 years and older
Positive screening requires clinical evaluation for diagnosis
